httpserver

Class HTTPHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • httpserver.HTTPHandler
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    FileHandler, HelloHandler, MathHandler, MessageHandler

    public abstract class HTTPHandler
extends java.lang.Object
    An HTTPHandler is what all handlers used by your server descend from.

    HTTPHandlers also deal with the server -> client transmission of data, making it easy to adjust how data is sent to the client.

    Extended classes have two options for determining their actions: they may override the handle method (slightly harder), or use the addGet and addPost methods in the constructor. See their descriptions for more information.

    If you just want to send a static message to the client, regardless of request, you can use a MessageHandler, instead of creating a new Handler.

    See Also:
    handle(), addGET(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), addPOST(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)

    • Constructor Detail

      • HTTPHandler

        public HTTPHandler(java.net.Socket socket,
           HTTPRequest request)
            throws HTTPException
        Create an HTTPHandler.

        This is where paths should be setup

        This also sets some acceptable defaults:

        • The response code is set to 200 (OK, which means everything happend all nice and good-like);
        • The response size is set to -1, which tells the HTTPResponse to determine the correct size when sends back the information;
        • The response is told it hasn't been handled yet;
        • And the response mimetype is set to "text/plain".
        Parameters:
        request - HTTPRequest with the browser's request information.
        Throws:
        HTTPException
        See Also:
        HTTPRequest, setResponseCode(int), setResponseSize(long), setHandled(boolean), setResponseType(java.lang.String)

    • Method Detail

      • handle

        public void handle()
            throws HTTPException
        Where the Handler handles the information given from the request and based off of the paths specified in the Handler.

        This can be overridden for more fine-grained handling. As is, it uses the data behind the addGET and addPOST methods for determining the correct action to take.

        If there is not exact match, the `*` and `/` path's are used, in that order. If, after that, no method can be found, a 501 is sent over to the client, with the NOT_A_METHOD_ERROR message.

        Throws:
        HTTPException - when an attached method can't be invoked.
        See Also:
        addGET(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), addPOST(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), NOT_A_METHOD_ERROR

      • message

        public void message(int code,
           java.lang.String message)
        Send a simple string message with an HTTP response code back to the client.

        Can be used for sending all data back.

        Parameters:
        code - An HTTP response code.
        message - The content of the server's response to the browser
        See Also:
        error(int, java.lang.String, java.lang.Throwable), noContent()

      • noContent

        public void noContent()
        Tell the browser there is no response data.

        This is done by sending over a 204 code, which means there isn't any data in the stream, but the server correctly processed the request

        See Also:
        message(int, java.lang.String)

      • error

        public void error(int code,
         java.lang.String message,
         java.lang.Throwable t)
        Send a message to the browser and print an exception

        Prints the stackTrace of `t`, and sends a message `message` back to the browser, with that HTTP status of `code`

        Parameters:
        code - HTTP status code
        message - the content being sent back to the browser
        t - A throwable object, to be printed to the screen
        See Also:
        message(int, java.lang.String)

      • addGET

        public void addGET(java.lang.String path,
          java.lang.String methodName)
            throws HTTPException
        Attach a method to a GET request at a path.

        Methods are passed in using "className#methodName" form so that we can parse out the correct Method. Who knows, you might want to use a method somewhere else, and who are we to argue with that?

        If no # is included, we assume it belongs to the class it's called in.

        Path's should come in "/path/to/action" form. If the method requires parameters, they should be included in the path, in the order they're listed in the method definition, but in "{ClassName}" form. Example: /hello/{String}/{String} is a good path.

        Methods being used should only have parameters that are included in the java.lang library. Any other type of parameter will cause an exception to occur.

        Additionally, primitives are not permited, because they're not classes in the java.lang library.

        Parameters:
        path - Path to match
        methodName - Class and Method in class#method form.
        Throws:
        HTTPException - When you do bad things.
        See Also:
        addPOST(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)

      • addPOST

        public void addPOST(java.lang.String path,
           java.lang.String methodName)
             throws HTTPException
        Attach a method to a POST request at a path.

        For a more detailed explanation, see addGET.

        Parameters:
        path - Path to match
        methodName - Class and Method in class#method form.
        Throws:
        HTTPException - When you do bad things.
        See Also:
        addGET(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)

      • respond

        public void respond()
        Send data back to the client.

        If the response hasn't been handled, try handling it, and sending that data back to the client.

        This method only writes the headers, and calls writeData() to send the determined response back to the client. This is done because the headers are fairly global, and shouldn't need to be changed, where the actual response data might need some "special sauce".

        See Also:
        writeData()

      • writeData

        public void writeData()
               throws java.io.IOException
        Send the actual response back to the client.

        Where the actual data is sent back to the client. If a child handler has non-generic text data to be sent, this is what should be modified.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        See Also:
        respond()
